author: sky.cactus
content: Whoa, someone actually closed a Draft PR after I suggested that it was a "Good Idea" rather than a "standard".  üéâ

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!425279588009246720> I'm curious both why the bot didn't flag https://github.com/ethereum/EIPs/pull/1297 for closure?  Any ideas?

author: sky.cactus
content: Oh, maybe you touched it a day or two before the bot ran.

author: axic3354
content: The bot only touched around 30% of the issues, it rans out of execution time. With every PR closed it gets an opportunity to mark new ones üò¨

author: sky.cactus
content: Ah, interesting.

author: sky.cactus
content: So in a couple weeks it'll do another big batch presumably?

author: axic3354
content: There's a new addition every few days

author: sky.cactus
content:
Re: https://hackmd.io/@axic/eip-overhaul
> During this stage it is expected that the draft is discussed at least by a smaller group of interested participants.
A great standard can be written by one passionate individual, and a really terrible standard can be written by a committee.  I'm generally against anything that requires some quorum because it is likely to result in shilling, sock puppets, and brigading.

author: sky.cactus
content: <@!425279588009246720> I think the EIP-overhaul document would benefit from listing the criteria for moving something from one stage to the next.  You have timeframe in there, but I think it is important to include editor criteria as well.  For example, for something to move into Draft it has to have its front matter filled out and be properly formatted.  For something to move into Candidate it has to be in the form of a specification without any open questions, incomplete sections, and written targeting the proper audience (readers 5 years in the future wanting to implement the specification).

author: sky.cactus
content: Same for Proposed and Final/Living.

author: axic3354
content: Hm, that's a great point.

author: sky.cactus
content: In other news, Micah would love it if all of the editors would agree with them that EIPs should have a target audience of "5-year future implementers".  üò¨

author: sky.cactus
content:
>     obsoleted-by: contains a single EIP number which obsoletes this EIP
This shouldn't come as a surprise to the regulars around here, but I'm against this field.  Once an EIP is final, I am of the opinion that the author no longer has any special authority over it.  The EIP has been released into the public domain and now exists as part of public record.  It cannot be changed in any normative way by the author, and I generally feel that the author shouldn't even have special privilege when it comes to changing the non-normative parts either.

author: sky.cactus
content: This stance includes declaring whether a particular EIP is a "good idea" or not anymore.

author: sky.cactus
content: A great example of this is ERC-20.  Should the author of that EIP be able to declare that ERC-5432 is the token standard that obsoletes ERC-20, and none of the other 100 token standards that were created between ERC-20 and ERC-5432 obsoleted it?  I believe they shouldn't, and since there is no reasonable way to come to community consensus around which of those 100 tokens is the "official deprecator of 5432", there shouldn't be any way to assert that.

author: axic3354
content: We should have a look at how RFCs decide on obsoletion, because they make a very frequent use of it.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe they have an authoritative committee, which makes a lot of problems easier.  üò¨

author: sky.cactus
content: Unless we want editors to become authorities over the EIPs repository (rather than just grounds keepers), I don't see that as a viable solution.

author: axic3354
content: It just works well with the errata. If there's no obsoletion then the errata process needs to be extended, by probably adding "errata only" EIPs.

author: axic3354
content: One of the examples of obsoletion is EIP-820+EIP-1820.

author: sky.cactus
content: I would be OK with an author being able to set `obsoleted-by` on an abandoned EIP, and maybe even having a `reason` for `replaced-by XXX` or something.

author: axic3354
content: That was another option I had üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: Did 820 make it to final before 1820 was created?

author: axic3354
content: Yes

author: axic3354
content: It was final for 6 months or so ?

author: sky.cactus
content: Then my response to that is: Create a new EIP (1820) and live with the fact that 820 has a problem.

author: axic3354
content: Exactly that's what is going on, and there's a mention of this problem in 820 pointing to 1820.

author: axic3354
content: Errata/Obsoletion, it is a related process.

author: axic3354
content: I agree obsoletion should not be abused to randomly mark things which have no problems out of marketing reasons.

author: axic3354
content:
An "easy fix" for the obsoletion is two allow it in two cases:
1. On non-Final as suggested in the doc (e.g. authors come to an agreement)
2. On Final only in case the errata can not be placed in the document (as explained in the doc)

I think this would cover both cases where obsoletion is used/useful.

author: sky.cactus
content: I think *everyone* agrees that ERC-20 is terrible and *should* be obsoleted.  üôÇ

author: axic3354
content: Well then they can submit an errata and reasoning üôÇ

author: sky.cactus
content: That feels like a recipe for politics, which I'm trying to avoid.

author: axic3354
content: I understand your position, that especially in the case of ERC-20 there is no good choice, but at the same time I don't want to rule out useful features because of ERC-20.

author: sky.cactus
content: Even for the 820 => 1820 case, I don't feel like there is a clear path to making that a non-political process.

author: sky.cactus
content: That particular case "worked" merely because no one happened to fight it I think.

author: sky.cactus
content: But I also think it is an incredibly dangerous path to go down for the editors, because it turns us into curators (e.g., censors of sorts).

author: madeof_tin7509
content:
> I'm phrasing this based on #2941:
> 
> And editor can only mark it `status="Withdrawn" reason="no activity"` . Hopefully if someone implements a bot, the bot can do it, but bots wont write themselves (at least not yet). I do not think this is a political step as long it is clearly stated in EIP-1.
> 
> `status="Withdrawn" reason="by author"` can only be set by the author, again not an editor decision.
<@425279588009246720>  

The specific reason why this won't work is because it relies on reading and understanding a technically accurate definition that conflicts with the common understanding of the word.

an Example is the definition of Accepted.

‚ÄùThis status signals that material changes are unlikely and Ethereum client developers should consider this EIP for inclusion. Their process for deciding whether to encode it into their clients as part of a hard fork is not part of the EIP process.‚Äù

Referring to progpow, people read Accepted and assumed into mainet. Even though the definition specifically said this is not the case. Even among core devs this was mistaken.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Keeping it a ‚Äùnot a politicol step if clearly stated in EIP.‚Äù won't keep politics out. Politics doesn't or doesn't care to read.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: A status that clearly separates from an easy human psychology perspective will.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: If an EIP is changed to Stangnant there is no room for confusion as to why.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Also remember that politics doesn't care about being technical correct. They will bend whatever fits for them to be correct.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: If EIP editors can move things to stagnant, but not to withdrawn. There is a clear separation between what is what. If the editors can move a status to withdrawn that opens space for confusion, and misuse by editors.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: I am not saying any editor here today would, I am saying 3-4 years from now we don't know who is going to be editors and why.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Protecting the process from politics is important imo.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Important enough to have both Stagnant, and Withdrawn

author: sky.cactus
content: I agree that protecting the process from politics is important, and it is my number one goal in most things.  I'm incredibly dubious on the claim that people will read "Withdrawn", proceed to *not* read the reason that is paired with it, and then somehow start a political fight over that status.

author: sky.cactus
content: And even if someone did manage to do this, it is trivial to point it out to them.

author: sky.cactus
content:
I think that in order for the EIPs repository to function we have to assume at least some basic level of reading comprehension by readers, and to me turning the following into something political crosses that lower bound:
```
status: Withdrawn
reason: Author Non-responsive
```

author: sky.cactus
content: Perhaps if you can give an example of how someone could misinterpret that and turn it into something political it would help me understand where you are coming from <@!187490121698770945>.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> I am saying 3-4 years from now we don't know who is going to be editors and why
Similar argument here, I feel like there is a minimum level of competency required to be an editor, and being able to follow basic rules like "editors shouldn't withdraw an EIP with a reason 'by author'" is a minimum requirement IMO.  If they make a mistake, no big deal as we can just fix it (e.g., undo), and if they make the same mistake over and over again then they probably shouldn't be an editor.  Also, I sincerely hope that in 3-4 years we have a stagnant bot that is doing all this so editors basically never move something to withdrawn.

author: sky.cactus
content: To approach this from a different angle: We could try withdrawn + reason (it has the advantage of giving a single status for "no longer being worked on") and if it ends up causing a bunch of political fights we can change it.  I generally dislike the idea of adding more statuses in fear that people are going to interpret them wrong without evidence yet that they will.  Worst case scenario, we can do a find and replace and switch from `status: Withdrawn; reason: Author Non-resonsive` to `status: Stagnant` without too much difficulty (especially if we are strict on formatting in the frontmatter across the repository, which I generally advocate for anyway).

author: sky.cactus
content: Note: I still favor merging the stuff that was agreed on in the call first.

author: axic3354
content: After reading all the above, if the assumption is that people won't read the "reason" field, then it will never be possible to move something from "Stagnant" to "Withdrawn" without the explicit confirmation from the author.

author: axic3354
content: Because then one cannot expect that those authors who are planning to turn it "political", will not do that when it moves into Withdrawn, eventually.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> After reading all the above, if the assumption is that people won't read the "reason" field, then it will never be possible to move something from "Stagnant" to "Withdrawn" without the explicit confirmation from the author.
I assumed this would be the case even with your proposal (can't move from withdrawn for unresponsiveness to withdrawn by author).

author: madeof_tin7509
content: That is fine.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: If it doesn't move to withdrawn then it doesn't move to withdrawn.

author: axic3354
content:
> That is fine.

Does that mean Stagnant is pretty much a final state?

author: madeof_tin7509
content: That should be up to the author. Not the Editors

author: madeof_tin7509
content: If it stays stagnant yes.

author: axic3354
content: It is highly unlikely an author will ever respond to anything whose EIP becomes stagnant in the first place.

author: axic3354
content: So why does the chart has Stagnant -> Withdrawn then?

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Feels uncomfortable to me for an author to Mark something as withdrawn.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Because it can go from stagnant to withdrawn.

author: axic3354
content: Basically you are introducing the Abandoned vs. Withdrawn split, just call it Stagnant.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Feels uncomfortable to me for an author to Mark something as withdrawn.
Really?  I have withdrawn several of my own EIPs.  What makes you uncomfortable with it?

author: madeof_tin7509
content: You can skip stagnant if you want and go directly to Withdrawn up to the authors

author: madeof_tin7509
content: I meant Editor. Sorry

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Authors would be the one to withdrawn an EIP

author: axic3354
content: An editor would move it to "Withdrawn due to inactivity", not "Withdrawn by the request thy author".

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Brb; in the middle of something.

author: madeof_tin7509
content:
> Really?  I have withdrawn several of my own EIPs.  What makes you uncomfortable with it?
<@301186049323958275>  yes I have withdrawn a few of my own as well.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: That is how it should be.

author: sky.cactus
content: I believe we all agree on two distinct states.  The only disagreement seems to be on the way those two states are expressed within the EIP metadata.

author: madeof_tin7509
content: Subjective calls by Editors is not a good direction.

author: sky.cactus
content:
> Subjective calls by Editors is not a good direction.
I believe we all agree with this statement, and I don't think any proposal on the table at the moment goes against this.

author: axic3354
content: Not sure how "Withdrawn due to inactivity" is subjective? It is governed by a set timeframe which must elapse without anyone touching the file, and this rule must be clearly stated in EIP-1.

author: axic3354
content: I do no think any Editor feels particularly empowered to act in their own ways without adhering to the rules defined in EIP-1.

author: axic3354
content: To make sure we are on the same page, when I say "Withdrawn due to inactivity" I mean `status=Withdrawn withdrawal-reason=No activity`, which means two fields in the EIP header.

author: axic3354
content: Important to mention that Withdrawn is not a terminal state, any time it can be "resurrected" and moved to Draft. The only terminal state is Final. Perhaps we should just call that Terminal? üôÇ
